description.narrative: Reduction of Natural Resource-Based Conflict among Pastoralists and Farmers
Budgeting of 2015 TRAC.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Increased, strengthened and expanded number of and capacity of human resources for government lead actors in understanding basic conflict handling mechanisms 2. Technical criteria developed to determine flashpoint conflicts using objective data collection and analysis 3. Government structures and systems developed for government lead actors for workload management and coordination 4. Increase in number and expansion in capacity of recovery/development activities in project areas reflecting enhanced conflict sensitivity 5. Acquired conflict handling knowledge and skills are reflected in government lead actors’ design and approach to targeting flashpoint conflicts 6. Increase in numbers and diversification of key stakeholders engaged by government lead actors in support of peace processes 7. Increase in number of coordinated linkages/projects/activities between recovery interventions and peace-led government processes 8. Inclusion of conflict sensitive practices in outcomes of recovery projects linked to peace processes

comment.narrative: • Government lead actors have received limited/ no technical training in conflict handling. • Government lead actors have received limited/ no institutional development support. • Targeted flashpoint conflicts determined based on political (not technical) criteria • Low levels of internal and external coordination by government lead actors with key stakeholders. • Limited range of approaches utilized to analyze and address flashpoint conflicts by government lead actors. • Peace conferences carried out as ‘one-off’ events with insufficient preparation/follow-up • Low levels of engagement of women and youth and other key stakeholders in government-led peace processes • Peace agreements achieved with some degree of political pressure • Government-led peace processes lack coordinated support to address identified causes of conflict • Post-conflict community needs identified without technical review or prioritization • Post-conflict recovery projects not implemented in conflict sensitive manner • Critical resources and lessons learned regarding conflict handling / conflict sensitivity not shared among key stakeholders

Output 1:Government and community – led peace building initiatives supported to promote stability, inter-communal reconciliation and peaceful coexistence • Target: 3 mechanisms for mediation and consensus building with core functions clearly defined • Target: 3 mechanisms for mediation and consensus building with responsibilities and core functions clearly assigned • Target: 3 mechanisms for mediation and consensus building with budgets allocated • Target: 3 mechanisms for mediation and consensus building with action plans being implemented • Target: Increased capacity of Government partners to promote stability, inter-communal reconciliation and peaceful co-existence (10%) Output 2: Current and future local flashpoint conflicts are mitigated through inclusive peace processes. • Target: 70% of JCRP supported peace process holding after 12 months. • Target: 100 % of peace conferences carried out with the equal representation of the total number of conflicting parties. • Target: 50% of peace building training workshops, peace conference or dialogue participants from vulnerable groups (women, youth, elderly, persons with disabilities). Output 3: Local stakeholders are linked to high-level peace processes through dialogue and dissemination of information. • Target: 3 briefing session and dialogues conducted between local level and high level peace actors with the support of JCRP

Output 1: Government and community – led peace building initiatives supported to promote stability, inter-communal reconciliation and peaceful coexistence • 3 Mechanisms are in place; the PC in BNS, the RPCM in WKS and the SPPCC in SKS (Source: Government Decrees) • The PC does have a budget allocated but the SPPCC and RPCM do not as yet. • All 3 peacebuilding mechanisms have action plans in place. • Repeat Assessments of Government partners perceived capacities to promote stability, inter-communal reconciliation and peaceful co-existence are due to take place in Q4 2015, the PC has 10% increase in graded score.
Output 2: Current and future local flashpoint conflicts are mitigated through inclusive peace processes. • 94% (or 16/17) of JCRP supported peace processes continued to hold after 12 months (Source: State Peacebuilding Mechanisms) •100 % of peace conferences carried out with the equal representation of the total number of conflicting parties. • One peace conference was held in June in SKS with 50% active participation from vulnerable groups.
Output 3: Local stakeholders are linked to high-level peace processes through dialogue and dissemination of information. • Three dialogues sessions between local level and high level peace actors with the support of JCRP were conducted in 2015: 1) 88 community peacebuilders, representatives from State-level mechanisms, and CSOs took part in the Peace Ambassador Forum held in Khartoum, March 2015, 2) during 3 days consultations in Khartoum in May 2015, more than 35 community peacebuilders from SKS, WKS, Abyei, BLN, and Darfur took part in a dialogue facilitation session and peacebuilding consultation at the University of Khartoum, 3) in September 2015, more than 400 people from SKS, WKS, BNS, Abyei and Darfur participated in the Sudan Peace Symposium (SPS) co-organized by UNDP/JCRP and the University of Khartoum. The participants included high-level government representation, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, State-lev

description.narrative: 1. National Mine Action Authority (NMAA) and Southern Sudan Demining Commission (SSDC) capacitated to implement their mandate and lead the mine action activities 2. No. of national de-miners trained/equipped/field deployed for clearance of mine/ERW affected areas. 3. 3,000-4,000 of the declared 5,000 stockpiled antipersonnel mines destroyed in accordance with the UN approved international standards. 2. Southern Sudan Mine Action Legislative Framework developed and presented to the Southern Sudan Legislative Assembly 4. Mine Action Transition plan developed and endorsed. 5. Two 2 Mine Risk Education (MRE) Teams and Three Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD) Teams established and deployed to high priority areas/communities for MRE and EOD activities.

comment.narrative: 1. No destruction of the declared 5,000 stockpiled antipersonnel mines has taken place in Southern Sudan. 2. Except for GOSS presidential Decree # 45, there is no legislative framework in place for mine action in Southern Sudan. 3. There is no mine action transition plan in place. 4. There are a number of national and international organizations operating in the field of Mine Risk Education (MRE) and Explosive Ordnance Disposal (EOD).

1.1 Market monitoring information produced and used to boost livelihoods and local economies through trade in VC commodities. 1.2 Peacebuilding/Conflict mitigated: % change through increased personal investment in peace & cross tribal trade of VC commodities. 2.1 Trade routes map developed and produced across the 5 Darfur States; Related Value chain actors mapped. 5 State/interstate action plans identifying opportunities and constraints to trade by commodity developed by stakeholders in a participatory manner and adopted; 3.1 Average % increase of net annual income of reached SMEs, producer groups and households 3.2/3.3/3.4 % of women and vulnerable groups income and decision making participating in each value chains. 4.1 # of MSMEs opened/expanded 4.2 # of jobs created in VC commodities, by-products and spillover effects. 5.1 % income increase as a result of pricing transparency, access to MF and access to new markets. 5.2 % loan repayment rate to Micro-Finance Institutions (MFIs); 6.1 # direct linkages facilitated between producers and input suppliers and markets. 7.1 Analysis report on cereal trade in Darfur produced and recommendations to support rural livelihoods adopted and implemented by all relevant partners and stakeholders at different governance levels in Darfur;

comment.narrative: 1.1 No Market monitoring information produced and income survey to be conducted 1.2 No Peacebuilding/Conflict mitigated: % change through increased personal investment in peace & cross tribal trade of VC commodities. 2.1 No commodity maps exist; peace corridor maps are available although shifting. No State/interstate action plans identifying opportunities and constraints to trade by commodity developed by stakeholders in a participatory manner and adopted; 3.1 No Average HH net income at project’s first entry point 3.2/3.3/3.4 No income and decision making participation increase amongst women and vulnerable groups. 4.1 No MSMEs opened/expanded. 4.2 No jobs created in VC commodities, by-products and spillover effects. 5.1 No Income baseline in targeted VC communities 5.2 No access to MF and repayment rate 6.1 No direct linkages facilitated between producers and input suppliers and markets 7.1 No agreed strategy in place to support livelihoods of rural cereal producers. Limited export of Sudan cereals even when the export market is advantageous over the local market.

1.1 MMTA data collection and dissemination coverage expand by 25% 1.2 At least 5000 new beneficiaries have regular access to market information of which 40-50% are female. 1.3 85% of recipients regard the information as relevant and high quality. 1.4 At least 25% beneficiaries increased income due to access to MMTA information. 2.1 2010 Value Chain Analyses Reviewed and updated 2.2 At least 2 new commodities identified and analysed 2.3 New baseline assessment conducted conducted and established benchmark for M&E 3.1 15-30% increase in gross annual incomes of beneficiary SMEs, producer groups and households among which 50-60% are women and other vulnerable youth. 3.2 At least 50-60% of participants in value chain activities are women, IDPs/returnees, pastoralists and the youth across all value chains. 3.3 At least three new forward purchase contracts between producer groups and private sector purchasers. 3.4 At least 90% of aflatoxin test results between 0.5 and 3.5ppb against a minimum required quality threshold of 40ppb.

1.1 Target exceeded. The MMTA data collection and dissemination coverage has increased by 46% from 50 at the end of 2014 to 73 markets. 1.2 Target exceeded. One edition of the market information bulletin was produced as of end of June 2015. Up to 6000 copies were circulated in English and Arabic as well as using online and SMS channels, reaching approximately 6000 additional stakeholders of which 45% are female. 1.3 A user perception survey is planned in December 2015 to gauge the relevance and quality of the MMTA and the extend of its coverage. 1.4 The user perception survey that is planned to take place in December 2015 will cover the beneficiaries report on their average income increase as a result of using the MMTA bulletin. 2.1/2.2 The value chain analysis process has been initiated and will be completed within the fourth quarter of 2015. The analysis involve updating the existing Value Chain Analysis conducted in 2010, scoping and identifying new value chain commodities, mapping of trade routes and flows, mapping of value chain actors and identifying key obstacles within identified commodity value chain. 2.3 Baseline survey is ongoing, using standardized questionnaires across 4 states of Darfur (WD, SD, ND and CD) with the help of 1 implementing partner and will be completed by the end of December 2015. 3.1 An assessment is planned for the last quarter of 2015 which will gauge the average income increase. 3.2 Target achieved. So far, approximately 52% of participants in value chain activities are women, IDPs/returnees, pastoralists and youth. 3.3 In order to finalize the three new forward purchase contracts between producer groups and private sector purchasers, 2 local hibiscus processors in Sudan have been contacted and discussions with DAL company on the promotion and marketing of groundnuts. description.narrative: Darfur Field Offices Operations.
This project was set up to complement the new Darfur Field Office Structure in Geneina.
independent political entity
Strengthened ER operational and coordination capacity (including repositioning capacity) of UNDP and Partners.
seat of a first-order administrative division

- RRR Sector operating effectively and improved coordination of ER activities - Knowledge and skills of UNDP and partners on ER enhanced through technical expertise and training - ER priorities reflected consistently across different humanitarian sectors and a coherent plan for the Sudan HWP strategic objectives of resilience and durable solutions in place

comment.narrative: - ER-gap Sector established, named the Recovery, Return and Reintegration (RRR) Sector - Capacity UNDP to meet expectations as sector lead nationally and in Darfur needs to be strengthened - Cross-sectoral prioritization of ER remains weak and uneven within current Humanitarian Planning and Coordination

Output 1: 1.1 At least 5 sectors have ER priorities reflected in them 1.2 Strategy paper on ER, resilience and durable solutions developed for Sudan 1.3 Twelve RRR sector coordination meetings conducted in Khartoum and sector established in Darfur 1.4 Four UNDP dedicated staff for RRR recruited and UNDP’s capacity as sector lead strengthened

Activity Result 1: Target achieved. In the 2015 Humanitarian response plan (HRP), 5 sectors have reflected ER approaches in their humanitarian sector plans and during consultations in preparation of the 2016 HRP all sectors have agreed to reflect ER approaches in their sector plans and all are aiming to identify better linkages between humanitarian response and longer-term recovery in Sudan. However the overall 2016 HRP has been delayed and is not yet finalized. Activity Result 2: Target achieved. The RRR sector has build capacity in key staff from Humanitarian Aid Commission and Darfur Regional Authorities in support of a national-owned Durable Solutions (DS) Strategy for IDPs in Sudan in line with international standards. Strategies for ER & DS have been developed and fed into the 2016 HRP consultation meetings. Activity Result 3: Target on track -The RRR sector has conducted 11 sector meetings in Khartoum and has planned one more meeting for December 2015. Due to delay in recruitment, the sector in Darfur has not been established. However, consultation meetings have taken place in Darfur in preparation of the establishment of the RRR sector. Activity Result 4: Target achieved - Three UNDP dedicated staff have been recruited. As per the plan, the fourth staff, for UNDP's capacity to lead ER coordination, has been realized through the short-term recruitment of an Early Recovery Advisor to the HC/RC

1.1 Locality plans linked to the state Strategic Plan 1.2 The State budget linked to planning framework 1.3 State Macro-economic policy formulated 2.1 -Enactment of state financial laws 2.2 Amendment to state Local Government laws to clarify fiscal roles between Federal, state and localities 2.3 State administrative, accounting and finance regulations established 3.1 Institutionalized budget policy analysis and management function 3.2: Planning office established 3.3: MoLG coordinates capacity development for localities 3.4: Roles for public planning and expenditure management clarified 4.1: Number of laws reviewed 4.2: Number of policies reviewed 4.3: Level of harmonisation in institutional mandates and functions 5.1 Regular rhythm of policy dialogue under the Forum; 5.2 Regular rhythm of engagement with donors; 6.1: implementation structures established 6.2: Key Staff Recruited 6.3: Implementation agreements secured 6.4: Programme financing secured

comment.narrative: 1.1 - GFS classification has only been introduced in RSS 1.2 - all the three states do not have an institutionalised budget policy function and the budgets are not guided by macro-economic analysis 1.3 - revenue predictions are inadequate and unreliable (up to 60% shortfalls) severely affecting the predictability of budget implementation 2.1 None of the 3 state has the required laws and regulations for financial and procurement management 2.2 Gaps in fiscal relations between state and local government level leading to overlapping or confusing roles in revenue and expenditure management and accountability 2.3 Gaps in fiscal relations between state and federal government leading to confusing roles in fiscal policy management 3.1 Institutional roles for budget policy analysis and management are not clearly defined leading to overlap and gaps in implementation 3.2 there are no locality planning units in the states of Kassala and Gedaref while in RSS only 5 of the 10 localities have locality plans 3.3 in all the 3 states the public expenditure policy management function is lacking 3.4 organisational and financial management skills are low across the states leading to planning and budget formulation 4. lack of a coordinated legal, policy and institutional reform programme; lack of policy coordination mechanism; overlapping legal frameworks and institutional mandates; low public service out put 5. Eastern Sudan Forum has not worked as a forum in mobilising 3 states towards objectives of the ESPA 6.- Programme implementation structures not established

- 2.1.1. at least 2 training programmes in core local governance functions - 2.1.2. legislative forums conducted and 2 strategies reviewed - 2.2.1. at least 120 staff 80 males and 40 female on planning) trained within the planning department in the state ministries of finance in the East and South Kordofan - 2.3.1. Number of 60 youth (30 F/30M) engaged in training on local governance development issues - A.1.1.1. Finalized and approved AWP 2015 - A.1.2.1. At least four case stories developed and shared each quarter - A.1.2.2. At least 8 visits paid to various location of the project A.2.1.1 risks and issues updated quarterly for the project .3.2.1. LGDPEM Project experience produced by experts

- 2 training workshop conducted in Gedarif State for new government executives on core local governance functions - 65 staff were trained on project management in Gedarif State (35 males and 30 female) represented from Ministry of Finance. - 70 youth (4 F/30M) were trained in Kassala State on electronic data management - 40 staff (22 males and 18 females) were trained on SPSS data analysis for in Ministry of Finance in Gedarif State. - 6 staff from East Sudan (Kassala, Red Sea and Gedarif states) participated in a study tour in Ethiopia, and were exposed to the planning, revenue mobilization and public finance management in Ethiopia. - 4 monitoring visits paid to various location of the project. - Project risks and issues updated in ATLAS - Impact study of the LGDPEM Project conducted in Kassala state as a case study.

description.narrative: The project aims at improving the State governments’ capacity to collect taxes and prioritize public expenditures. Improved public expenditure management with strengthened planning capacity will be instrumental in optimising delivery of public services.

The project aims at improving the State governments’ capacity to collect taxes and prioritize public expenditures. Improved public expenditure management with strengthened planning capacity will be instrumental in optimising delivery of public services.
seat of a first-order administrative division
Accountability - local government finance
1. Increase in revenue collection 2. Number of institutions at state and locality level with computerized payroll system 3. Number of SSP reviewed and prioritized for three states

comment.narrative: 1. Local revenue too low amounting to only 15% (ND), 20% (SD) and 3.5% (WD) of total revenue receipts in 2009 (ND) and 2010 (SD & WD). 2. No Standard guidelines for revenue collection and reporting in place. 3. Budget departments facing difficulties to apply the GFS as it was imposed from the national Government without provision of requisite training. 4. Payroll is done manually resulting in errors and huge payroll arrears. 5. Strategic planning is still at its infancy and therefore needs strengthening.

Output 1 10% increase in local revenue collection 100 booklets/guidelines developed & distributed to localities 10 teams applying GFS system in selected localities for the year
Output 2 10 line ministries and 10 selected localities prepare GFS conforming budget 90 staff from line ministries and pilot localities trained on GFS.
Output 3 20% of line ministries and 20% of localities level decrease in reporting inconsistencies 10 line ministries and 10 selected localities apply the adopted GFS system
Output 4 5 State Ministries of Finance equipped with computerized payroll system and routinely using it 1 audit conducted 20% decrease in payroll arrears
Output 5 Guide for strategic planning developed & 100 copies distributed 200 staff at state and locality levels trained on strategic planning process.
Two preliminary audits were undertaken in West and South Darfur

title.narrative: Strengthening Capacity of Sudan National Human Rights Co

description.narrative: SNHRC is the country’s national human rights institution established in 2012.
SNHRC is the country’s national human rights institution established in 2012. The main objective is to support the SNHRC in the development of its capacities to be in line with the Paris Principles.
independent political entity
Human rights affairs

1 •SNHRC offices functioning and operational at the national and state levels; •15 SNHRC Commissioners functioning in line with Paris Principles and international human rights instruments •Number of SNHRC’s laws and policies aligned with International Norms and Standards;
2 •A strategic plan developed for promotion and protection of human rights across Sudan •% of ordinary Sudanese are aware of their human rights of the role of human rights commission in the protection and promotion of human rights •Number of human right cases transferred to the concerned institutions, .i.e. judiciary, police, etc. disaggregated by gender and backgrounds; 3 •Number of human rights research and analyses reports conducted. •Number of journalists with various media houses gained knowledge in various areas of human rights •Number of ordinary Sudanese reached out through human rights campaigns and aware of the existence of SNHRC; 4 •Number of SNHRC’s personnel trained on human rights norms and Paris Principles •Baseline survey on knowledge of monitoring techniques

comment.narrative:
1
• 0 (zero) organizational structure or secretariat exists for SNHRC. • 0 (zero) operational policies and policy documents exist for SNHRC that are in line with Paris Principles; • SNHRC Commissioners are less aware of human rights norms and standards
2 • No Capacity Assessment conducted for SNHRC • No SNHRC report on human rights situation in Sudan available • Limited awareness of the role of the SNHRC by the ordinary Sudanese
3 • No research and analyses reports conducted by SNHRC • No human rights awareness campaigns conducted by SNHRC
4 •Despite ratifying a number of international treaties, there is no national institution with activities that aim at promoting and protecting human rights across Sudan.

description.narrative: The project overall objective is to contribute to achieving aid effectiveness in Sudan through strengthening aid management and aid policy coordination

Indicators Output1: 1.Number of government staff members o responsible for aid coordination functions whose capacities have significantly been improved 2.Improvement in organizational performance in units of MoFNE responsible for aid coordination (the organizational performance will be monitored through a capacity review in 2014) Indicators Output2: 1. Percentage of programmes included in SAID for which regularly updated M&E data is available 2. Percentage of projects included in SAID for which regularly updated M&E data is available

comment.narrative:
Baseline output1: 1. Following the government restructure in 2012, the government Directorates responsible for aid management and coordination have been organized according to new institutional and coordination set up in the government. 2. Capacities of government officials responsible for aid management and coordination needs to be further developed to manage aid coordination after government restructuring 3. No comprehensive capacity assessment has been carried out for the government units and staff members responsible for aid management and coordination. 4. No comprehensive capacity development plan has been developed and implemented for the government units and staff members responsible for aid management and coordination
Baseline Output2: 1. SAID project module has been completed successfully. 2. SAID Fund Expectation module has been completed. 3. SAID programme and aid effectiveness modules have not been completed 4. Aid M&E and information systems are not integrated and harmonized
Baseline Output3:
1. Government aid policy coordination between relevant directorates of the MoFNE (budget, policies, aid management and coordination and development directorates) needs strengthening especially after the government restructuring 2. There are no sufficient aid dialogue and coordination structures including government and development partners 3. A draft Sudan Aid Strategy has been formulated

title.narrative: Climate Risk Finance for Sustainable & Climate Resilient

description.narrative: Climate Risk Finance for Sustainable & Climate Resilient for sustainable agricultural and pastoral system in Sudan
The full pledge document is at formulation stage and approval Climate Risk Finance for Sustainable & Climate Resilient

‎1.Number of small-‎holder rain-fed ‎farmers and ‎pastoralist ‎households with ‎access to MF or ‎MF/WII products ‎ ‎ ‎2.Domestic finance ‎committed to the ‎relevant institutions ‎to monitor extreme ‎weather and climate ‎change

comment.narrative:
‎1. MFIs/Insurance companies ‎have limited capacity to provide ‎tailored financial services for ‎smallholder rain-fed farmers and ‎pastoralists. Current products are ‎too generalized and do not ‎consider flexible payment cycles ‎and reasonable compensation ‎criteria. MFIs/Insurance ‎companies have not found means ‎to access the remote, rural areas ‎‎(e.g., mobile units), organize the ‎farmers/pastoralists nor mitigate ‎their associated risks. As a result, it ‎is common that ‎farmers/pastoralists use informal ‎lending services. ‎BASELINE:93,500 with access to ‎MF, 0 with access to MF/WII; ‎
‎2.Existing budget plans do not ‎have sufficient funds to maintain ‎and operate environmental ‎monitoring infrastructure. ‎BASELINE: Annual O&M budgets ‎for weather and climate ‎monitoring institutions are ‎approximately, MoWRE: USD ‎‎223,000, RSA: USD 100,000 ‎and SMA: 300,000.‎ ‎1.Currently, weather and ‎climate monitoring ‎coverage in the target ‎States is limited. Most ‎equipment is manual and ‎up to 40% of equipment ‎is not-functional. A ‎BASELINE of what is ‎operational includes in ‎the 6 target States ‎includes the following:‎ Meteorological stations: ‎‎28 manual, 32 automatic Hydrology equipment: 17 ‎water level, 4 manual and ‎‎1 automatic flow meters‎ Rain gauges:‎ ‎98 manual‎
‎2.There are existing ‎regional and community-‎based EWS initiatives for ‎food security, however, a ‎national alert system ‎concerned with extreme ‎hydro-meteorological ‎phenomena is lacking. ‎ There is also a limited ‎understanding of ‎technical weather/climate ‎information jargon (e.g., ‎alerts are not translated ‎into all national dialects). ‎There is also no ‎formalized ‎communication ‎mechanism for alerts and ‎weather/climate ‎information. End-users ‎cannot provide feedback ‎to improve the ‎communication process.‎ BASELINE ‎% Women who receive ‎EWS alerts‎ states: 5%‎ ‎% Men who receive EWS ‎alerts/CI in target states: ‎‎10%‎
‎3. BASELINE Bulletins are currently ‎produced se

comment.narrative: 1. Two criminal justice forums established at regional level (one in Darfur and one in eastern Sudan) and quarterly meetings held 2. 100 complaints received and no data on caseload age 3. No office existing outside of Khartoum 4. 300 representatives of the judiciary, prosecutors, police and prison staff and social workers trained in human rights and 47 social workers 5. 82 parliamentarians and legal advisors trained on importance of law reform for child law and women’s law 6. UPR action Plan for the UPR process developed 7. 30% of people report high confidence in and easy access to rule of law institutions overall; 20% women report high confidence; 22% reported easy access (2013) 8. 4 Legal aid network (LAN) organizations and 4 JCCs in Darfur were fully functional and active during 2013 9. Two legal aid desks established in the selected prisons in Darfur but not yet effectively functional 10. There is little knowledge on the alternative dispute resolution mechanisms 11.Limited monitoring visits to support project implementation by staff

1. Two criminal justice forums established at regional level (one in Darfur and one in eastern Sudan) and quarterly meetings held 2. 6 strategic planning sessions provided to selected justice sector institutions 3. 70% of citizens report confidence in and easy access to rule of law institutions 4. 6 refresher courses for GoS prisons officers on human rights approach to prisons management and 6 training courses for newly recruited prisons officers conducted in all five Darfur states for 300 participants 5. 1 underground water tank (250,000 liters) and 1 elevated water tank (40,000 liters) constructed at Shallah Federal Prison in El Fasher to address water needs 6. 6 vocational and livelihood skills training workshops established and tools and equipment for welding and metal works, carpentry, masonry, auto-mechanics, and tailoring procured in 6 Darfur prisons (Shallah Federal Prison in El Fasher; Kheir Khanaga Women Prison in El Fasher; Central Prison in Nyala; Ardamata Prison in El Geneina; Zalingei Prison; and El Daein Prison 7. # senior police management and leadership M/F trained on strategic planning 8. Civilian Oversight Mechanisms drafted through 2 consultations and workshops 9. Special committee on Darfur in place and strategic priorities for Darfur established 10. 200 relevant government officials have improved their human rights knowledge and enhanced the implementation of Sudan obligations under human Rights treaties 11. Progress towards revision of 4 laws (Child Act, Press Act, Criminal Act and law related to women’s rights) 12. Sets of indicators and timelines to monitor UPR implementation progress developed and included into the UPR Action Plan 13. 50% report high confidence overall; 30% women report high confidence; 30% report easy access. 14. Target: 300 clients (30% women) assisted with legal aid counselling at the 8 existing JCCs across Darfur and 150 clients in eastern Sudan 15. 10 NGOs and CBOs participating in access to justice trainings

1) Overall progress for output 1: improve justice, security and human rights provided by state actors through more effective, equitable and timely protection services: Implementation of activities to improve the capacity of Justice, Security and human Rights Institutions is progressing well. Vocational training were developed and delivered with the participation of various stakeholders including UNAMID, Police and Prison Section with government ministries (Prosecutor, Prison and Police). Implementation of the 5 Year Strategic plan for prison development is progressing well (17F & 113M) prison officers benefited from Human rights approach to prisons management for prison officers. Fair trial and legal aid related principles have been incorporated into training models for prosecutors and lawyers (123F & 267M). Similarly, management and leadership skills, criminal investigation, with focus SGBV were delivered to police officers (8F & 56M). To increase the extension of police service Community policing volunteers training models were delivered with the participation of IDPs, community leaders, women groups, youth (445F & 356M). Special efforts have also been made improve Darfur Transitional Justice institutions to fight impunity and promote reconciliation with a Witness and Victims Protection Strategy along with UNAMID Human Rights Section. Implementation of UPR Recommendations is progressing well. Data collection around the implementation of UPR is showing that 85% of UPR Recommendations have been implemented, with the amendment of Criminal Law, Election Law and the adoption of Human Trafficking Law and Access to Information Law and Regulation of Refugees Law. Access to legal aid and protection for vulnerable groups strengthened
2) Overall progress for Output 2: Access to legal aid and protection for vulnerable groups strengthened : With the goal of scaling up the provision of legal aid and enhance legal awareness efforts in multiple provinces in five Darfur States an

Overall progress of output 4: Complaint Management infrastructure strengthened: internal regulations of the Complaints Committee revised with oversight and governance role of the Complaints Committee, with Complaints Manual and standard forms covering the management process for the entire life cycle of a case have been developed. In order to increase the visibility of the SNHRC and of the Complaints Committee in particular, an outreach programme was organized for 70 people, including over 10 members of the media.
Overall Progress of Output 5 Engagement in Darfur: Workshop was organized in Khartoum with representatives from Darfur, UNAMID Human rights Section to establish the new Committee on Darfur and define its road map or strategic plan for the opening of the SNHRC in Darfur, and arrangements are underway to launch the Darfur Branch in December
Overall Progress of output 6: Commissioners and staff capacity to perform respective functions through the delivery of targeted training and professional developed: Significant results have been achieved in developing internal policies. A two-day training for the Commissioners and the staff of the Complaints Committee was held, and 7 operational policies were developed: 1 internal regulation and 3 key operational procedures for the Complaints Committee (as annexes to the Complaints Manual) ; 1 ethics/conflict of interest policy; 1 Staff Recruitment policy; 1 job description template

comment.narrative: Since 2014, Sudan has witnessed an upsurge in conflict-induced displacement. In order to address the needs of these newly displaced people, as well as those people who have been displaced for a number of years, the protection sector has identified a number of priority areas to guide interventions in 2015. These interventions will be carried out in collaboration with the Government of Sudan, relevant protection institutions and humanitarian organisations.

description.narrative: Refugee Multi-Sector Support
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

comment.narrative: Sudan hosts around 171,000 refugees and asylum seekers from a range of countries: Eritrea, Ethiopia, Chad, (CAR), the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), Somalia and Syria. Around 92,000 live in eastern Sudan, another 32,000 in Khartoum, and around 45,000 in Darfur. Sudan also has over 90,000 Sudanese in Darfur who were previously refugees in Chad, and have now returned to their country of origin, but not all to their area of origin. Finally, there are also potentially 350,000 individuals of South Sudanese origin (of which around 40,000 reside in Khartoum) who had been living in Sudan prior to secession that did not flee conflict. They have an unclear legal status and so are potentially at risk of statelessness.

This project has been established in line with UNDP’s role as Managing Agent of the Sudan Common Humanitarian Fund/Country Based Pooled Fund as detailed in the CHF/CBPF’s Terms of Reference and Accountability Framework . The project serves to channel allocations to NGOs for allocation round 1 / 2015 of the CHF. The total amount of resources allocated and transferred to NGOs in the Refugee multi Sector Cluster for round 1 / 2015 in 2015 was USD 689,488.24

title.narrative: Leapfrogging Sudan’s markets to effecient appliances

description.narrative: The project is promoting the use of efficient electrical appliances and will be implemented under the UNEP Efficient Appliances Global Program Framework Document (PFD). The lead GEF agency will be UNDP.
Assessment of the national energy efficiency and lighting regulatory and support mechanisms currently in place in Sudan, including the National Energy Efficiency Action plan (NEEAP)
Health - policy, planning and administration
project document prepared

comment.narrative: Various ad-hoc efforts are being made by different government entities such as the Ministry of Water Resources, Electricity and Irrigation, which has an initiative to replace one million Incandescent Lamps (ICLs 60-100W) with high-quality, long life (10,000 hours) energy efficient Compact Fluorescent Lamps (CFL). In line with electricity efficiency efforts, the Sudanese Standards and Meteorology Organization (SSMO) is establishing a laboratory for testing performance of all electrical appliances. Different electrical appliance performance testing equipment have been procured and are expected to be installed by December 2015. The Electricity Regulatory Authority is also keen on developing new regulatory measures for EE; at present the country has no MEPS for any appliances or equipment. Moreover the Arab Regional Center for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency (RCREEE) initiated a series of workshops targeting public utilities, companies, universities and other stakeholders on developing the capacities for promoting energy efficiency actions.
Recruitment of consultants and start project preparation
International consultant and two national consultants were recruited to develop the project document.
